values.description: Slight improvement to pull request #650: Add a temporary variable to hold the separator string, so as to avoid the chance of subsequent errors in indexing based on its length.
values.title: Add temporary string variable

values.description:
Merging forward pull request #650 so that we can release a new sdf9, and in turn create a new citadel docker image for some folks.

This is the same content as pull request #650, which has been approved. So, I'll let CI do it's thing and then merge if there are no objections.

values.description:
The strictness of the DOM parser has been causing some issues with gazebo11. It currently drops any DOM objects that have any errors, or whose children have errors. This can quickly wipe out an entire world or model if there is one problematic tag. This PR relaxes the templated `loadRepeated` and `loadUniqueRepeated` functions in `src/Utils.hh` so that objects are kept even if they generated errors.

For example, see the `InertialInvalid` test in link_dom.cc: the invalid inertial was preventing the entire link from being loaded, causing `MODEL_WITHOUT_LINK` errors. Those errors are gone now.

Note that this can also generate more errors, since building the `FrameAttachedToGraph` and `PoseRelativeToGraph` can generate multiple error messages that derive from the same problem. For an example, see the `LoadInvalidJointChildWorld` test case in joint_dom.cc (console output pasted below):

~~~
[ RUN      ] DOMJoint.LoadInvalidJointChildWorld
Error Code 18 Msg: Joint with name[joint] specified invalid child link [world].
Error Code 18 Msg: Child link with name[world] specified by joint with name[joint] not found in model with name[joint_child_world].
Error Code 23 Msg: FrameAttachedToGraph error, Non-LINK vertex with name [joint] is disconnected; it should have 1 outgoing edge in MODEL attached_to graph.
Error Code 23 Msg: Graph has __model__ scope but sink vertex named [joint] does not have FrameType LINK when starting from vertex with name [joint].
Error Code 18 Msg: Child link with name[world] specified by joint with name[joint] not found in model with name[joint_child_world].
Error Code 26 Msg: PoseRelativeToGraph error, Non-MODEL vertex with name [joint] is disconnected; it should have 1 incoming edge in MODEL relative_to graph.
Error Code 26 Msg: PoseRelativeToGraph frame with name [joint] is disconnected; its source vertex has name [joint], but its source name should be __model__.
[       OK ] DOMJoint.LoadInvalidJointChildWorld (34 ms)
~~~
values.title: Keep DOM objects even if they were loaded with errors

summary.raw:
The strictness of the DOM parser has been causing some issues with gazebo11. It currently drops any DOM objects that have any errors, or whose children have errors. This can quickly wipe out an entire world or model if there is one problematic tag. This PR relaxes the templated `loadRepeated` and `loadUniqueRepeated` functions in `src/Utils.hh` so that objects are kept even if they generated errors.

For example, see the `InertialInvalid` test in link_dom.cc: the invalid inertial was preventing the entire link from being loaded, causing `MODEL_WITHOUT_LINK` errors. Those errors are gone now.

Note that this can also generate more errors, since building the `FrameAttachedToGraph` and `PoseRelativeToGraph` can generate multiple error messages that derive from the same problem. For an example, see the `LoadInvalidJointChildWorld` test case in joint_dom.cc (console output pasted below):

~~~
[ RUN      ] DOMJoint.LoadInvalidJointChildWorld
Error Code 18 Msg: Joint with name[joint] specified invalid child link [world].
Error Code 18 Msg: Child link with name[world] specified by joint with name[joint] not found in model with name[joint_child_world].
Error Code 23 Msg: FrameAttachedToGraph error, Non-LINK vertex with name [joint] is disconnected; it should have 1 outgoing edge in MODEL attached_to graph.
Error Code 23 Msg: Graph has __model__ scope but sink vertex named [joint] does not have FrameType LINK when starting from vertex with name [joint].
Error Code 18 Msg: Child link with name[world] specified by joint with name[joint] not found in model with name[joint_child_world].
Error Code 26 Msg: PoseRelativeToGraph error, Non-MODEL vertex with name [joint] is disconnected; it should have 1 incoming edge in MODEL relative_to graph.
Error Code 26 Msg: PoseRelativeToGraph frame with name [joint] is disconnected; its source vertex has name [joint], but its source name should be __model__.
[       OK ] DOMJoint.LoadInvalidJointChildWorld (34 ms)
~~~
summary.html:
The strictness of the DOM parser has been causing some issues with gazebo11. It currently drops any DOM objects that have any errors, or whose children have errors. This can quickly wipe out an entire world or model if there is one problematic tag. This PR relaxes the templated loadRepeated and loadUniqueRepeated functions in src/Utils.hh so that objects are kept even if they generated errors.

For example, see the InertialInvalid test in link_dom.cc: the invalid inertial was preventing the entire link from being loaded, causing MODEL_WITHOUT_LINK errors. Those errors are gone now.

Note that this can also generate more errors, since building the FrameAttachedToGraph and PoseRelativeToGraph can generate multiple error messages that derive from the same problem. For an example, see the LoadInvalidJointChildWorld test case in joint_dom.cc (console output pasted below):

[ RUN      ] DOMJoint.LoadInvalidJointChildWorld
Error Code 18 Msg: Joint with name[joint] specified invalid child link [world].
Error Code 18 Msg: Child link with name[world] specified by joint with name[joint] not found in model with name[joint_child_world].
Error Code 23 Msg: FrameAttachedToGraph error, Non-LINK vertex with name [joint] is disconnected; it should have 1 outgoing edge in MODEL attached_to graph.
Error Code 23 Msg: Graph has __model__ scope but sink vertex named [joint] does not have FrameType LINK when starting from vertex with name [joint].
Error Code 18 Msg: Child link with name[world] specified by joint with name[joint] not found in model with name[joint_child_world].
Error Code 26 Msg: PoseRelativeToGraph error, Non-MODEL vertex with name [joint] is disconnected; it should have 1 incoming edge in MODEL relative_to graph.
Error Code 26 Msg: PoseRelativeToGraph frame with name [joint] is disconnected; its source vertex has name [joint], but its source name should be __model__.
[       OK ] DOMJoint.LoadInvalidJointChildWorld (34 ms)

values.description: This fixes #219 by checking `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` before rotating joint axis in the parser's `addNestedModel` function. I've added a test that includes 3 different `double_pendulum_with_base` models, first as a model directly in the world, then then twice as nested models from sdf 1.4 and sdf 1.5. The sdf 1.4 model will have `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in == "__model__"`, so it will retain the rotation behavior, but the model loaded from sdf 1.5 will not be rotated.
values.title: parser addNestedModel: only rotate joint axis xyz if expressed_in == '__model__' (#219)

summary.raw: This fixes #219 by checking `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` before rotating joint axis in the parser's `addNestedModel` function. I've added a test that includes 3 different `double_pendulum_with_base` models, first as a model directly in the world, then then twice as nested models from sdf 1.4 and sdf 1.5. The sdf 1.4 model will have `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in == "__model__"`, so it will retain the rotation behavior, but the model loaded from sdf 1.5 will not be rotated.
summary.html: This fixes #219 by checking //axis/xyz/@expressed_in before rotating joint axis in the parser's addNestedModel function. I've added a test that includes 3 different double_pendulum_with_base models, first as a model directly in the world, then then twice as nested models from sdf 1.4 and sdf 1.5. The sdf 1.4 model will have //axis/xyz/@expressed_in == "__model__", so it will retain the rotation behavior, but the model loaded from sdf 1.5 will not be rotated.

values.description:
Most of the headers that had references to `TinyXML` were not actually installed, so I moved them to `src` in cb2ef1e. The `URDF2SDF` class uses `TinyXML` in its API so, in 49fa563, I put `URDF2SDF` inside the namespace `internal` and created an alias with the same name that is deprecated. i.e, `sdf::URDF2SDF` is deprecated for external users while `sdf::internal::URDF2SDF` is fine for internal use.

`nm -C -D --defined-only src/libsdformat9.so | grep TiXml` now shows 
```
00000000000d57f0 T sdf::v9::internal::URDF2SDF::InitModelDoc(TiXmlDocument*)
00000000000d2d10 T sdf::v9::internal::URDF2SDF::ParseSDFExtension(TiXmlDocument&)

```
values.title: Remove TinyXML symbols from public API

summary.raw:
Most of the headers that had references to `TinyXML` were not actually installed, so I moved them to `src` in cb2ef1e. The `URDF2SDF` class uses `TinyXML` in its API so, in 49fa563, I put `URDF2SDF` inside the namespace `internal` and created an alias with the same name that is deprecated. i.e, `sdf::URDF2SDF` is deprecated for external users while `sdf::internal::URDF2SDF` is fine for internal use.

`nm -C -D --defined-only src/libsdformat9.so | grep TiXml` now shows 
```
00000000000d57f0 T sdf::v9::internal::URDF2SDF::InitModelDoc(TiXmlDocument*)
00000000000d2d10 T sdf::v9::internal::URDF2SDF::ParseSDFExtension(TiXmlDocument&)

```
summary.html:
Most of the headers that had references to TinyXML were not actually installed, so I moved them to src in cb2ef1e. The URDF2SDF class uses TinyXML in its API so, in 49fa563, I put URDF2SDF inside the namespace internal and created an alias with the same name that is deprecated. i.e, sdf::URDF2SDF is deprecated for external users while sdf::internal::URDF2SDF is fine for internal use.

nm -C -D --defined-only src/libsdformat9.so | grep TiXml now shows 

00000000000d57f0 T sdf::v9::internal::URDF2SDF::InitModelDoc(TiXmlDocument*)
00000000000d2d10 T sdf::v9::internal::URDF2SDF::ParseSDFExtension(TiXmlDocument&)

values.description: Place the shared libraries to bin folder for Windows. By convention \(like Conda, Conan, ROS, vcpkg…\), the shared library files `.dll` on Windows should be placed under `bin` folder.
values.title: [Windows] Place the shared libraries .dll to bin folder for Windows.

summary.raw: Place the shared libraries to bin folder for Windows. By convention \(like Conda, Conan, ROS, vcpkg…\), the shared library files `.dll` on Windows should be placed under `bin` folder.
summary.html: Place the shared libraries to bin folder for Windows. By convention (like Conda, Conan, ROS, vcpkg…), the shared library files .dll on Windows should be placed under bin folder.

values.description:
Added the surface DOM with a contact object to store surface properties.

For now it only implements a single property \(collide\_bitmask\), since it is already a quite large piece of code I thought I’d check if it is correct from a style / idea point of view before adding the rest of the parameters \(friction related\).

Apart from the unit tests, a high level test can be done using the new collide\_bitmask feature in the ign-physics branch, specifically in ign-physics:

```
hg checkout add_surface_dom
<rebuild>
ign gazebo -v 4 shapes_bitmask.sdf
```

Result on my machine \(on ogre1\):

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/ak8x4z/images/902803472-image.png)
Any feedback on style, API design, etc. more than welcome as always.

The main part I find tricky to understand is how to modify properties in subelements of a root node \(and if it should be allowed\).  
For example, since a function such as 

`const *Contact Cont() const`

Doesn’t allow modifying all the underlying properties, which means that it’s illegal to do:

```
sdf::Surface surface;
surface.Cont()->SetCollideBitmask(0x12);
```

But the only way to do such change is to replace the whole Contact subelement:

```
sdf::Contact contact;
contact.SetCollideBitmask(0x12);
surface.SetCont(contact);
```

Is this behavior intended?
values.title: [WIP] Adding surface DOM

For now it only implements a single property \(collide\_bitmask\), since it is already a quite large piece of code I thought I’d check if it is correct from a style / idea point of view before adding the rest of the parameters \(friction related\).

Apart from the unit tests, a high level test can be done using the new collide\_bitmask feature in the ign-physics branch, specifically in ign-physics:

ign gazebo -v 4 shapes_bitmask.sdf

Result on my machine \(on ogre1\):

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/ak8x4z/images/902803472-image.png)
Any feedback on style, API design, etc. more than welcome as always.

The main part I find tricky to understand is how to modify properties in subelements of a root node \(and if it should be allowed\).  
For example, since a function such as 

`const *Contact Cont() const`

Doesn’t allow modifying all the underlying properties, which means that it’s illegal to do:

```
sdf::Surface surface;
surface.Cont()->SetCollideBitmask(0x12);
```

But the only way to do such change is to replace the whole Contact subelement:

```
sdf::Contact contact;
contact.SetCollideBitmask(0x12);

```

Is this behavior intended?
summary.html:
Added the surface DOM with a contact object to store surface properties.

For now it only implements a single property (collide_bitmask), since it is already a quite large piece of code I thought I’d check if it is correct from a style / idea point of view before adding the rest of the parameters (friction related).

Apart from the unit tests, a high level test can be done using the new collide_bitmask feature in the ign-physics branch, specifically in ign-physics:

hg checkout add_surface_dom
<rebuild>
ign gazebo -v 4 shapes_bitmask.sdf

Result on my machine (on ogre1):

Any feedback on style, API design, etc. more than welcome as always.

The main part I find tricky to understand is how to modify properties in subelements of a root node (and if it should be allowed).
For example, since a function such as

const *Contact Cont() const

Doesn’t allow modifying all the underlying properties, which means that it’s illegal to do:

sdf::Surface surface;
surface.Cont()->SetCollideBitmask(0x12);

But the only way to do such change is to replace the whole Contact subelement:

sdf::Contact contact;
contact.SetCollideBitmask(0x12);
surface.SetCont(contact);

Is this behavior intended?

values.description:
Fix the typo for tinyxml\_INCLUDE\_DIRS.

Under the `src/CMakeLists.txt` and `test/CMakeLists.txt`, they are using `tinyxml_INCLUDE_DIRS` as the CMake variable name, and CMake variables are case sensitive.

‌
values.title: Fix the typo for tinyxml_INCLUDE_DIRS.

summary.raw:
Fix the typo for tinyxml\_INCLUDE\_DIRS.

Under the `src/CMakeLists.txt` and `test/CMakeLists.txt`, they are using `tinyxml_INCLUDE_DIRS` as the CMake variable name, and CMake variables are case sensitive.

‌
summary.html:
Fix the typo for tinyxml_INCLUDE_DIRS.

Under the src/CMakeLists.txt and test/CMakeLists.txt, they are using tinyxml_INCLUDE_DIRS as the CMake variable name, and CMake variables are case sensitive.

‌

values.description: This pull request is to make `USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML` as an option and which makes `sdformat` portable to other package managers \(conda, conan, vcpkg, etc…\).
values.title: [Windows] make USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML as an option.

values.description: As part of updating the sdformat.org/spec page, we need to generated aggregated SDFormat descriptions for each version of SDFormat. This PR adds a cmake target to do so. Part of that was to make `ign sdf -d` take an optional `version` argument. The PR also updates the `upload_docs.sh` script to upload the generated description files to S3.
values.title: Add functionality to generate the aggregated SDFormat description via CMake

summary.raw: As part of updating the sdformat.org/spec page, we need to generated aggregated SDFormat descriptions for each version of SDFormat. This PR adds a cmake target to do so. Part of that was to make `ign sdf -d` take an optional `version` argument. The PR also updates the `upload_docs.sh` script to upload the generated description files to S3.
summary.html: As part of updating the sdformat.org/spec page, we need to generated aggregated SDFormat descriptions for each version of SDFormat. This PR adds a cmake target to do so. Part of that was to make ign sdf -d take an optional version argument. The PR also updates the upload_docs.sh script to upload the generated description files to S3.

values.description: SDF is an acronym that has other meanings in robotics, so we are trying to be consistent about calling the specification "SDFormat" and the parsing library "libsdformat". I only updated the description files in this PR because they are the ones used to generate the sdformat.org/spec page
values.title: Rename SDF to SDFormat/libsdformat

summary.raw: SDF is an acronym that has other meanings in robotics, so we are trying to be consistent about calling the specification "SDFormat" and the parsing library "libsdformat". values.description:
Nested models currently do not support frame semantics because frames from child models are added to the parent model without any transformation. This PR adds the necessary name and pose transformations to add support for models nested using the `<include>` tag. This PR also injects the frame `<model_name>::__model__`,  into the parent model so that the child model's frames, links, and joints are can reference this frame instead of transforming their poses. This is a precursor to full support for composition.

Eg. The following is the original child model
```
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.7">
  <model name="test_model_with_frames">
    <frame name="F1">
      <pose>0 0 0 1.570796 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <frame name="F2">
      <pose relative_to="F1">0 0 0 0 0.785398 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <link name="L1">
      <pose relative_to="F1"/>
    </link>
    <link name="L2">
      <pose relative_to="F1">1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </link>
    <joint name="J1" type="revolute">
      <pose relative_to="L1"/>
      <parent>L1</parent>
      <child>L2</child>
      <axis>
        <xyz expressed_in="F2">0 0 1</xyz>
      </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>
```
and the parent model nesting `test_model_with_frames` as `M1`
```
<sdf version='1.7'>
  <world name='default'>
    <model name='ParentModel'>  
      <include> 
        <uri>/path/to/test_model_with_frames/</uri>
        <name>M1</name>
        <pose>10 0 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose>
      </include>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
```
The parsed model (with some extra tags removed for clarity) will be
```
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.7'>
  <world name='default'>
    <model name='ParentModel'>
      <frame name='M1::__model__' attached_to='M1::L1'>
        <pose relative_to='__model__'>10 0 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose>
      </frame>
      <frame name='M1::F1' attached_to='M1::__model__'>
        <pose>0 0 0 1.5708 -0 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <frame name='M1::F2' attached_to='M1::__model__'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::F1'>0 0 0 0 0.785398 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <link name='M1::L1'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::F1'>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      </link>
      <link name='M1::L2'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::F1'>1 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      </link>
      <joint name='M1::J1' type='revolute'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::L1'>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <parent>M1::L1</parent>
        <child>M1::L2</child>
        <axis>
          <xyz expressed_in='M1::F2'>0 0 1</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
```
The parsed model before this PR:
```
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.7'>
  <world name='default'>
    <model name='ParentModel'>
      <frame name='F1'>  <!-- Frame name not transformed -->
        <pose>0 0 0 1.5708 -0 0</pose>  <!-- Pose not transformed -->
      </frame>
      <frame name='F2'> <!-- Frame name not transformed -->
        <pose relative_to='F1'>0 0 0 0 0.785398 0</pose> <!-- Pose not transformed -->
      </frame>
      <link name='M1::L1'>
        <pose relative_to='F1'>10 0 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose> <!-- Pose transformed but still relative to F1. Resolved pose is incorrect -->
      </link>
      <link name='M1::L2'>
        <pose relative_to='F1'>10 1 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose> <!-- Pose transformed but still relative to F1. Resolved pose is incorrect -->
      </link>
      <joint name='M1::J1' type='revolute'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::L1'>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <parent>M1::L1</parent>
        <child>M1::L2</child>
        <axis>
          <xyz expressed_in='F2'>0 0 1</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
```

Edit: Update rotation angles of F1 and F2 and add more comments for clarity.
values.title: Support frame semantics in for models nested with <include>

summary.raw:
Nested models currently do not support frame semantics because frames from child models are added to the parent model without any transformation. This PR adds the necessary name and pose transformations to add support for models nested using the `<include>` tag. This PR also injects the frame `<model_name>::__model__`,  into the parent model so that the child model's frames, links, and joints are can reference this frame instead of transforming their poses. This is a precursor to full support for composition.

Eg. The following is the original child model
```
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.7">
  <model name="test_model_with_frames">
    <frame name="F1">
      <pose>0 0 0 1.570796 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <frame name="F2">
      <pose relative_to="F1">0 0 0 0 0.785398 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <link name="L1">
      <pose relative_to="F1"/>
    </link>
    <link name="L2">
      <pose relative_to="F1">1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </link>
    <joint name="J1" type="revolute">
      <pose relative_to="L1"/>
      <parent>L1</parent>
      <child>L2</child>
      <axis>
        <xyz expressed_in="F2">0 0 1</xyz>
      </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>
```
and the parent model nesting `test_model_with_frames` as `M1`
```
<sdf version='1.7'>
  <world name='default'>
    <model name='ParentModel'>  
      <include> 
        <uri>/path/to/test_model_with_frames/</uri>
        <name>M1</name>
        <pose>10 0 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose>
      </include>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
```
The parsed model (with some extra tags removed for clarity) will be
```
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.7'>
  <world name='default'>
    <model name='ParentModel'>
      <frame name='M1::__model__' attached_to='M1::L1'>
        <pose relative_to='__model__'>10 0 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose>
      </frame>
      <frame name='M1::F1' attached_to='M1::__model__'>
        <pose>0 0 0 1.5708 -0 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <frame name='M1::F2' attached_to='M1::__model__'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::F1'>0 0 0 0 0.785398 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <link name='M1::L1'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::F1'>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      </link>
      <link name='M1::L2'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::F1'>1 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      </link>
      <joint name='M1::J1' type='revolute'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::L1'>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <parent>M1::L1</parent>
        <child>M1::L2</child>
        <axis>
          <xyz expressed_in='M1::F2'>0 0 1</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
```
The parsed model before this PR:
```
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.7'>
  <world name='default'>
    <model name='ParentModel'>
      <frame name='F1'>  <!-- Frame name not transformed -->
        <pose>0 0 0 1.5708 -0 0</pose>  <!-- Pose not transformed -->
      </frame>
      <frame name='F2'> <!-- Frame name not transformed -->
        <pose relative_to='F1'>0 0 0 0 0.785398 0</pose> <!-- Pose not transformed -->
      </frame>
      <link name='M1::L1'>
        <pose relative_to='F1'>10 0 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose> <!-- Pose transformed but still relative to F1. Resolved pose is incorrect -->
      </link>
      <link name='M1::L2'>
        <pose relative_to='F1'>10 1 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose> <!-- Pose transformed but still relative to F1. Resolved pose is incorrect -->
      </link>
      <joint name='M1::J1' type='revolute'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::L1'>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <parent>M1::L1</parent>
        <child>M1::L2</child>
        <axis>
          <xyz expressed_in='F2'>0 0 1</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
```

Edit: Update rotation angles of F1 and F2 and add more comments for clarity.
summary.html:
Nested models currently do not support frame semantics because frames from child models are added to the parent model without any transformation. This PR adds the necessary name and pose transformations to add support for models nested using the <include> tag. This PR also injects the frame <model_name>::__model__, into the parent model so that the child model's frames, links, and joints are can reference this frame instead of transforming their poses. This is a precursor to full support for composition.

Eg. The following is the original child model

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.7">
  <model name="test_model_with_frames">
    <frame name="F1">
      <pose>0 0 0 1.570796 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <frame name="F2">
      <pose relative_to="F1">0 0 0 0 0.785398 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <link name="L1">
      <pose relative_to="F1"/>
    </link>
    <link name="L2">
      <pose relative_to="F1">1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </link>
    <joint name="J1" type="revolute">
      <pose relative_to="L1"/>
      <parent>L1</parent>
      <child>L2</child>
      <axis>
        <xyz expressed_in="F2">0 0 1</xyz>
      </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>

and the parent model nesting test_model_with_frames as M1

<sdf version='1.7'>
  <world name='default'>
    <model name='ParentModel'>  
      <include> 
        <uri>/path/to/test_model_with_frames/</uri>
        <name>M1</name>
        <pose>10 0 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose>
      </include>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>

The parsed model (with some extra tags removed for clarity) will be

<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.7'>
  <world name='default'>
    <model name='ParentModel'>
      <frame name='M1::__model__' attached_to='M1::L1'>
        <pose relative_to='__model__'>10 0 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose>
      </frame>
      <frame name='M1::F1' attached_to='M1::__model__'>
        <pose>0 0 0 1.5708 -0 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <frame name='M1::F2' attached_to='M1::__model__'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::F1'>0 0 0 0 0.785398 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <link name='M1::L1'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::F1'>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      </link>
      <link name='M1::L2'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::F1'>1 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      </link>
      <joint name='M1::J1' type='revolute'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::L1'>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <parent>M1::L1</parent>
        <child>M1::L2</child>
        <axis>
          <xyz expressed_in='M1::F2'>0 0 1</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>

The parsed model before this PR:

<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.7'>
  <world name='default'>
    <model name='ParentModel'>
      <frame name='F1'>  <!-- Frame name not transformed -->
        <pose>0 0 0 1.5708 -0 0</pose>  <!-- Pose not transformed -->
      </frame>
      <frame name='F2'> <!-- Frame name not transformed -->
        <pose relative_to='F1'>0 0 0 0 0.785398 0</pose> <!-- Pose not transformed -->
      </frame>
      <link name='M1::L1'>
        <pose relative_to='F1'>10 0 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose> <!-- Pose transformed but still relative to F1. Resolved pose is incorrect -->
      </link>
      <link name='M1::L2'>
        <pose relative_to='F1'>10 1 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose> <!-- Pose transformed but still relative to F1. Resolved pose is incorrect -->
      </link>
      <joint name='M1::J1' type='revolute'>
        <pose relative_to='M1::L1'>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <parent>M1::L1</parent>
        <child>M1::L2</child>
        <axis>
          <xyz expressed_in='F2'>0 0 1</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>

Edit: Update rotation angles of F1 and F2 and add more comments for clarity.

values.description:
Added `visibility_flags` and `visibility_mask` to sdf 1.7 spec.

A visual will be visible to a camera if their visibility flags/mask evaluates to non-zero

example:

```
<camera name="camera">
  ...
  <visibility_mask>0x01</visibility_mask>
</camera>

<visual name="visual_1">
  ...
  <visibility_flags>0x01</visibility_flags>
</visual>

<visual name="visual_2">
  ...
  <visibility_flags>0x02</visibility_flags>
</visual>
```

camera should see `visual_1` but not `visual_2`

‌

[related ign-gazebo pull request](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/559/add-support-for-visual-visibility-flags/diff)
values.title: Add camera visibility mask and visual visibility flags

summary.raw:
Added `visibility_flags` and `visibility_mask` to sdf 1.7 spec.

A visual will be visible to a camera if their visibility flags/mask evaluates to non-zero

example:

```
<camera name="camera">
  ...
  <visibility_mask>0x01</visibility_mask>
</camera>

<visual name="visual_1">
  ...
  <visibility_flags>0x01</visibility_flags>
</visual>

<visual name="visual_2">
  ...
  <visibility_flags>0x02</visibility_flags>
</visual>
```

camera should see `visual_1` but not `visual_2`

‌

[related ign-gazebo pull request](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/559/add-support-for-visual-visibility-flags/diff)
